matrix.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 //! \mainpage The MatrixClass Library
00002 //!
00003 //! \section intro Introduction
00004 //! This class library is designed to make use of matrices and thier associated functions
00005 //! using the C++ programming enviromnent. It is designed to be as flexible as possible in
00006 //! both implementation and usage.
00007 //!
00008 //! \section implementation Implementation
00009 //! The matrix classes and thier derivatives come in three main types:
00010 //!
00011 //! \li <b>Stand-alone</b> (e.g. \a Matrix, \a SquareMatrix, \a RowVector ...)
00012 //! \li <b>Alias</b> (e.g. \a MatrixAlias, \a SquareMartixAlias, \a RowVectorAlias ...)
00013 //! \li <b>Constant alias</b> (e.g. \a MatrixAliasConstant, \a SquareMartixAliasConstant, \a RowVectorAliasConstant ...)
00014 //!
00015 //! \subsection implementation_standalone Stand-Alone Classes
00016 //! The stand-alone classes allocate and free thier own memory. They can be instantiated
00017 //! in many ways:
00018 //!
00019 //! \code
00020 //! Matrix A(2, 2);                 // 2x2 matrix
00021 //! RowVector x(4);                 // 4 element row vector
00022 //! ColumnVector y(ptr_to_data, 5); // 5 element column vector initiated with the values in an array
00023 //! Matrix B(A);                    // New matrix the same size as A, and initiated with the same values
00024 //! Matrix C = A;                   // New matrix the same size as A, and initiated with the same values
00025 //! \endcode
00026 //!
00027 //! \subsection implementation_alias Alias Classes
00028 //! The alias classes can be used to mask or alias another matrix object. This can be useful if you
00029 //! wanted to reference a matrix in a different way, but it can be particularly useful if you
00030 //! already have some data (say in an array), and you want to implement the functionality of
00031 //! the matrix class on that data. For example:
00032 //!
00033 //! \code
00034 //! void foo(double * data, int size)
00035 //! {
00036 //!     ColumnVectorAlias cva(data, size); // Use the data pointer to act as the storage for the new vector
00037 //!
00038 //!     // operations on cva...
00039 //! }
00040 //! \endcode
00041 //!
00042 //! Remember that you will be allocating your own memory for alias classes. In the above example
00043 //! the \c data pointer must point to at least <tt>size*sizeof(double)</tt> bytes of allocated memory.
00044 //!
00045 //! \subsection implementation_constantalias Constant Alias Classes
00046 //! In the situation where you are provided with read only data the constant alias class can be used
00047 //! to provive read only functionality. For example:
00048 //!
00049 //! \code
00050 //! void foo(const double * data, int size)
00051 //! {
00052 //!     RowVectorAliasConstant rvac(data, size); // Use the data pointer to act as read only storage for the new vector
00053 //!
00054 //!     // read operations on rvac...
00055 //! }
00056 //! \endcode
00057 //!
00058 //! \section usage Usage
00059 //! The matrix class library has been designed to be as intuative to use as possible. The matrix classes,
00060 //! and thier derived classes have certain operations available to them. Operatons are inherited or overridden
00061 //! in derived classes (whichever make most sense), so an operation like \c transpose() which is available in
00062 //! the \a Matrix class will also be available in its derived class \a SquareMatrix. However, a function like
00063 //! \c inverse() will be available to the \a SquareMatrix class, but not to the ordinary \a Matrix class.
00064 //!
00065 //!     To use an operator for a matrix, just call the associated function:
00066 //! \code
00067 //!    Matrix A(3,3);
00068 //!    Matrix B(3,3);
00069 //!
00070 //!    A.rand();            // Randomise the values of A
00071 //!
00072 //!    B = A.transpose();   // B becomes the transposed matrix of A
00073 //! \endcode
00074 //!
00075 //! Although the matrix operations look to be member functions of the \a Matrix class, they are in fact
00076 //! member \em objects. They are a special kind of object where each object has has its \c operator()
00077 //! method overloaded. These special member objects are called "Matrix Operators", and they all inherit
00078 //! from just two base classes: MatrixReadOperator and MatrixWriteOperator. The classes derived from
00079 //! MatrixReadOperator provide the read functions for the \a Matrix classes, and (you've guessed it!) the
00080 //! MatrixWriteOperator classes provide the write functions.
00081 //!
00082 //! Further derived classes, for example \a SquareMatrix, inherit the Matrix operations from Matrix,
00083 //! but also include their own set of operator classes derived from \a SquareMatrixReadOperator and
00084 //! \a SquareMatrixWriteOperator. Both of these inherit from MatrixReadOperator and MatrixWriteOperator
00085 //! respectively.
00086 //!
00087 //! Obviously the AliasConstant classes only contain read operators, while the other classes contain
00088 //! both read and write operators.
00089 //!
00090 //! For an exmaple, we can look at using a Matrix class, and a more specific SquareMatrix class. The SquareMatrix
00091 //! class contains both the Matrix read and write operators, and also the SquareMatrix read and write operatiors.
00092 //!
00093 //! \code
00094 //! Matrix m(10,5);                // 10x5 matrix
00095 //! SquareMatrix sm(5);            // 5x5 square matrix
00096 //!
00097 //! m.set(1.0);                    // make all elements in m equal 1.0
00098 //! m = m.multiply(5.34);          // multiply all elements in m by 5.34 and assign that back to m
00099 //! sm = sm.inverse();             // make sm equal to its own inverse
00100 //! sm = m.inverse();              // ERROR! m is not a square matrix
00101 //! \endcode
00102 //!
00103 //! \subsection usage_standardoperators Standard Operators
00104 //! There are many standard operators that have been overloaded to allow for a more readable code when using
00105 //! the matrix class library. These operators include:
00106 //!
00107 //! \li <b>Round brackets () </b> - for accessing matrix elements
00108 //! \li <b>Arithmetic operators +, -, *, / </b> - for performing aritthmetic operations with matricies
00109 //! \li <b>Assignment operator= </b> - for assigning one matrix's values (and size) to another
00110 //!
00111 //! Other operators may be overloaded for more specific (derived) matrix types.
00112 //!
00113 //! Example:
00114 //!
00115 //! \code
00116 //! // Implementing the state-space formula:
00117 //! //
00118 //! //     dx = Ax + Bu
00119 //! //
00120 //! ColumnVector stateEquation(ColumnVector x, ColumnVector u)
00121 //! {
00122 //!     Matrix A(3,3);            // A matrix
00123 //!     Matrix B(3,2);            // B matrix
00124 //!     ColumnVector dx(3);       // state derivative vector
00125 //!
00126 //!     // Create A & B matrices
00127 //!     A(0,0) = 5; A(0,1) = 17; A(0,2) = 0.034;
00128 //!     A(1,0) = 2.4;  // etc...
00129 //!
00130 //!     dx = (A * x) + (B * u);   // Perform state equation
00131 //!
00132 //!     return dx;                // Return state vector
00133 //! }
00134 //! \endcode
00135 //!
00136 //! \subsection usage_morestandardoperators More on Standard Operators
00137 //!     To give a little more insight to how the standard operators work it should
00138 //! be explained that they do no more than simply call the relevant Matrix Operator
00139 //! for the matrix to which they belong. Because of this, there are many Matrix Operators
00140 //! that belong to matrix classes that the user might otherwise never know existed.
00141 //! For every Standard Operator there will be a specific Matrix operator that is called,
00142 //! Operators like:
00143 //!
00144 //! \li \c multiply(operand) - Multiplies the matrix (or derivative) by the operand.
00145 //!     \li \c add(oparand) - Adds the matrix (or derivative) by the operand.
00146 //! \li \c negative() - Performs a unary minus on the matrix (or derivative).
00147 //! \li \c equals(operand) - Makes the matrix (or derivative) equal to its operand.
00148 //! \li \c element(index) - Retrives the indexed element of the matrix.
00149 //!
00150 //! These operators are called inline whenever the relevant Standard Operator is called.
00151 //! This means that the following code:
00152 //!
00153 //! \code
00154 //! dx = (A * x) + (B * u);   // Perform state equation
00155 //! \endcode
00156 //!
00157 //! Could equally have been written:
00158 //! \code
00159 //! dx.equals(A.multiply(x).add(B.multiply(u)));   // Perform state equation
00160 //! \endcode
00161 //!
00162 //! From that, hopefully you can see the benefits of using Standard Operators!
00163 //!
00164 //! \todo \b DONE Add rest of operators
00165 //! \todo \b DONE Add specific resize operators that only take one value for vectors and square matrices.
00166 //! \todo Create exception class and replace error() functions.
00167 //! \todo change return type for write operators (to return *this)
00168 //! \todo Test constructors fully
00169 //! \todo Test copy constructors fully.
00170 //! \todo Test assignment operators fully
00171 //! \todo Test SubMatrix class fully
00172 //! \todo Test/fix luDecomp and related functons (and cofactor() )
00173

00452 //! \brief An alias of a Matrix class, or to utilise a pre-available data array.
00453 //! \author Lee Netherton
00454 //!
00455 //! The MatrixAlias class provides a means to allow the aliasing of matrices, and
00456 //! also the flexibility to use external data storage made available be the user.
00457 //!
00458 //! For example:
00459 //!
00460 //! \code
00461 //! MatrixAlias giveMeAMatrix(int rows, int columns)
00462 //! {
00463 //!     double * dataPointer = new double[rows*columns];   // allocate some new memory
00464 //!
00465 //!     MatrixAlias newMA(dataPointer, rows, columns);     // create new MatrixAlias
00466 //!
00467 //!     return newMA
00468 //! }
00469 //! \endcode
00470 //!
00471 class MatrixAlias : virtual public MatrixAliasConstant
00472 {
00473         public:
00474 
00475                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00476                 //         Members
00477                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00478 
00479                 //! \brief Write access handle for the matrix
00480                 //!
00481                 //! Provides basic write funcions for all the write operators
00482                 MatrixWriteAccess * m_matrixWriteAccess;
00483 
00484 
00485                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00486                 //         MatrixOperator Members
00487                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00488 
00489                 //! Element operator
00490                 MWO_Element element;
00491 
00492                 //! Equals operator (makes the content of this matrix equal the values of another)
00493                 MWO_EqualsElementCopy equals;
00494 
00495                 //! Zero all the elements in the matrix
00496                 MWO_Zero zero;
00497 
00498                 //! Sets all the values in the matrix equal to a specified value
00499                 MWO_Set set;
00500 
00501                 //! Normalises the matrix
00502                 MWO_Normalise normalise;
00503 
00504                 //! Randomises all the values in the matrix to a values between 0 and specified value
00505                 MWO_Randomise rand;
00506 
00507                 //! Returns a subMatrixAlias of a portion of this matrix
00508                 MWO_SubMatrixAlias subMatrix;
00509 
00510 
00511                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00512                 //         Constructors
00513                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00514 
00515                 //! \brief Default constructor.
00516                 //!
00517                 //! Creates a MatrixAlias shell. The MatrixContainer, MatrixReadAccess, and MatrixWriteAccess
00518                 //! handles can be set later using the constructor function _constructMatrixAlias()
00519                 //MatrixAlias() {_constructMatrixAlias();}
00520 
00521                 //! \brief Pointer constructor
00522                 //!
00523                 //! To create a matrix that will access a pre-available data array.
00524                 //! \param data Pointer to data array. This will be the data storage for the matrix.
00525                 //! \param rows Number of rows the matrix has.
00526                 //! \param columns Number of columns the matrix has.
00527                 MatrixAlias(const double * data, const unsigned int rows, const unsigned int columns) : MatrixAliasConstant(data, rows, columns) {_constructMatrixAlias();}
00528 
00529                 //! \brief Alias constructor
00530                 //!
00531                 //! To create a matrix that will alias another matrix.
00532                 //! \param alias Pointer to a matrix which this matris will alias.
00533                 MatrixAlias(const MatrixAliasConstant* alias) : MatrixAliasConstant(alias->getDataPointer(), alias->getRows(), alias->getColumns()) {_constructMatrixAlias();}
00534 
00535                 //! \brief Copy constructor
00536                 //!
00537                 //! Used when creating a MatrixAliasConstant matrix from any other matrix.
00538                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.
00539                 MatrixAlias(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) : MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()) {_constructMatrixAlias();}
00540 
00541                 //! \brief Copy constructor
00542                 //!
00543                 //! Used when creating a MatrixAliasConstant matrix from another.
00544                 //! \code MatrixAliasConstant newMA(oldMA); \endcode
00545                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.
00546                 MatrixAlias(const MatrixAlias& copy) : MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()) {_constructMatrixAlias();}
00547 
00548                 //! \brief External container and access member constructor
00549                 //!
00550                 //! Used when the MatrixContainer and matrix access members have been created
00551                 //! externally (for example, in a submatrix). The MatrixAlias shell is
00552                 //! populated with operators and the handles are set.
00553                 //! \param container Pointer to MatrixContainer
00554                 //! \param r_access Pointer to MatrixReadAccess
00555                 //! \param w_access Pointer to MatrixWriteAccess
00556                 MatrixAlias(MatrixContainer * container, MatrixReadAccess * r_access, MatrixWriteAccess * w_access) : MatrixAliasConstant(container, r_access) {_constructMatrixAlias(w_access);}
00557 
00558 
00559         protected:
00560                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00561                 //         Constructor Functions
00562                 //------------------------------------------------------------

00565                 //!

00569

00571                 //!
00572                 //! Sets the pointers to the MatrixWriteOperator from an extenal source and passes rest to _constructMatrixAliasConstant().

00574 
00575

00577

00621                 MatrixAlias& operator*=(const double& operand);
00622 
00623                 //! Division assignment operator
00624                 MatrixAlias& operator/=(const double& operand);
00625 };

00628 //! \brief The standard matrix class.
00629 //! \author Lee Netherton
00630 //!
00631 //! The Matrix class provides the user with a pre made matrix. It will allocate
00632 //! its own memory, and is provided with a full complement of matrix operators.
00633 //!
00634 //! For example:
00635 //!
00636 //! \code
00637 //! Matrix A(3,3);        // Make a matrix called A
00638 //! Matrix B(3,3);        // Make a matrix called B
00639 //!
00640 //! // Fill the matrices with something useful
00641 //!
00642 //! Matrix C = A * B;     // Matrix C is the product of the two matrices
00643 //!
00644 //! \endcode
00645 //!
00646 class Matrix : virtual public MatrixAlias
00647 {
00648         public:
00649 
00650                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00651                 //         MatrixOperator Members
00652                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00653 
00654                 //! Equals operator - allows matrix to resize if it is made equal to one of a different size
00655                 MWO_EqualsElementCopyResize equals;
00656 
00657                 //! Resize operator Resize matrix (allocate new memory if number of elements changes).
00658                 MWO_Resize resize;
00659 
00660 
00661                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00662                 //         Constructors
00663                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00664 
00665                 //! \brief Default constructor.
00666                 //!
00667                 //! Creates a MatrixAlias shell. The MatrixContainer, MatrixReadAccess, and MatrixWriteAccess
00668                 //! handles can be set later using the constructor function _constructMatrixAlias()
00669                 Matrix() :
00670                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[1], 1, 1),
00671                         MatrixAlias(0, 1, 1)
00672                         {_constructMatrix();}
00673 
00674                 //! \brief Sized constructor.
00675                 //!
00676                 //! Creates a new matrix of a given size.
00677                 //! \param rows Number of rows matrix has
00678                 //! \param columns Number of columns matrix has
00679                 Matrix(const unsigned int rows, const unsigned int columns) :
00680                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[rows*columns], rows,columns),
00681                         MatrixAlias(0, rows, columns)
00682                         {_constructMatrix();}
00683 
00684                 //! \brief Base class copy constructor
00685                 //!
00686                 //! Makes a copy of any another matrix.
00687                 //! \param copy Reaference to matrix to copy
00688                 Matrix(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) :
00689                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[copy.getRows()*copy.getColumns()], copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()),
00690                         MatrixAlias(0, copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns())
00691                         {_constructMatrix(copy);}
00692 
00693                 //! \brief Copy constructor
00694                 //!
00695                 //! Makes a copy of another matrix.
00696                 //! \param copy Reaference to matrix to copy
00697                 Matrix(const Matrix& copy) :
00698                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[copy.getRows()*copy.getColumns()], copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()),
00699                         MatrixAlias(0, copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns())
00700                         {_constructMatrix(copy);}
00701 
00702 
00703         protected:
00704                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00705                 //         Constructor Functions
00706                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00707 
00708                 //! \brief Sized constructor
00709                 //!
00710                 //! Allocates some memory, and then calls MatrixAlias' constructor function
00711                 void _constructMatrix();
00712 
00713                 //! \brief Copy constructor
00714                 //!
00715                 //! Allocates some memory, and then calls MatrixAlias' constructor function.
00716                 //! Finally, copys data in from copied matrix
00717                 //! \param copy Matrix to copy
00718                 void _constructMatrix(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy);
00719 
00720         private:
00721 
00722                 //! \brief Operator constructor
00723                 //!
00724                 //! Constructs all the Matrix operator objects
00725                 void _constructMatrixWriteOperators();
00726 
00727         public:
00728                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00729                 //         Destructor
00730                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00731 
00732                 //! \brief Matrix Destructor
00733                 //!
00734                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
00735                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
00736                 virtual ~Matrix();
00737 
00738 
00739                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00740                 //         Overloaded Operators
00741                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00742 
00743                 //! Base class assignment operator
00744                 Matrix& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {equals(copy); return *this;}
00745 
00746                 //! Assignment operator
00747                 Matrix& operator=(const Matrix& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
00748 
00749 };
00750 
00751 
00752 //! \brief Accesses just a portion of a matrix.
00753 //! \author Lee Netherton
00754 //!
00755 //! The SubMatrixAliasConstant class can be useful for "masking" out, all but
00756 //! the useful parts of a matrix. Suppose you had a large matrix, but you only
00757 //! wanted to see the values in the top left corner of it:
00758 //! \code
00759 //!    void printJustASmallBit(Matrix& large_matrix)
00760 //!    {
00761 //!        SubMatrixAliasConstant small(large_matrix,0,4,0,4); // SubMatrix is a 5x5 matrix aliasing
00762 //!                                                            // the top corner of the large_matrix
00763 //!
00764 //!        small.print();        // print out the small section of the large_matrix
00765 //!    }
00766 //! \endcode
00767 //!
00768 class SubMatrixAliasConstant : virtual public MatrixAliasConstant
00769 {
00770         public:
00771                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00772                 //         Members
00773                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00774 
00775                 //! \brief A pointer to the SubMatrixContainer
00776                 //!
00777                 //! Only used to be able to make a copy of the SubMatrixContainer.
00778                 SubMatrixContainer * m_subMatrixContainer;
00779 
00780                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00781                 //         Constructors
00782                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00783 
00784                 //! \brief Default constructor.
00785                 //!
00786                 //! Creates a SubMatrixAliasConstant shell. The SubMatrixContainer and SubMatrixReadAccess
00787                 //! handles can be set later using the constructor function _constructSubMatrixAliasConstant()
00788                 //SubMatrixAliasConstant() {_constructSubMatrixAliasConstant();}
00789 
00790 
00791                 //! \brief Pointer constructor.
00792                 //!
00793                 //! Creates a SubMatrixAliasConstant from a pointer to another matrix. The other values
00794                 //! are the start and end rows and columns for the submatrix.
00795                 //! For example, supposre you had an 8x8 matrix, and you wanted to make a submatrix alias
00796                 //! the center 2x2 portion of it:
00797                 //!
00798                 //! \code
00799                 //!      Column Start (1)
00800                 //!             |Column End (2)
00801                 //!             |  |
00802                 //!  (0)  [ a | b  c | d ]
00803                 //!       [--------------]
00804                 //!  (1)  [ e | f  g | h ]-- Row Start (1)
00805                 //!       [   |      |   ]
00806                 //!  (2)  [ i | j  k | l ]-- Row End (2)
00807                 //!       [--------------]
00808                 //!  (3)  [ m | n  o | p ]
00809                 //!
00810                 //!        (0) (1)(2) (3)
00811                 //! \endcode
00812                 //!
00813                 //! Remembering that the matricies are zero indexed, the code to prodice such a submatrix
00814                 //! is as follows:
00815                 //! \code
00816                 //! Matrix A(8,8);                          // Create our 8x8 matrix
00817                 //!
00818                 //! SubMatrixAliasConstant subA(A,1,2,1,2); // Create the sub matrix
00819                 //!
00820                 //! subA.print();                           // Will produce: [ f g ]
00821                 //!                                                          [ j k ]
00822                 //! \endcode
00823                 //!
00824                 //! \param original Pointer to the matrix to be aliased
00825                 //! \param rowStart The index of the row to start the submatrix on
00826                 //! \param rowEnd The index of the row to stop the submatrix on
00827                 //! \param columnStart The index of the column to start the submatrix on
00828                 //! \param columnEnd The index of the column to stop the submatrix on
00829                 SubMatrixAliasConstant(const MatrixAliasConstant * original, const unsigned int rowStart, const unsigned int rowEnd, const unsigned int columnStart, const unsigned int columnEnd) :
00830                         MatrixAliasConstant(m_subMatrixContainer = new SubMatrixContainer(original->m_matrixContainer, rowStart, rowEnd, columnStart, columnEnd), new SubMatrixReadAccess(this))
00831                         {_constructSubMatrixAliasConstant();}
00832 
00833                 //! \brief Reference constructor.
00834                 //!
00835                 //! Creates a SubMatrixAliasConstant from a reference to another matrix. The other values
00836                 //! are the start and end rows and columns for the submatrix.
00837                 //! \param original Reference to the matrix to be aliased
00838                 //! \param rowStart The index of the row to start the submatrix on
00839                 //! \param rowEnd The index of the row to stop the submatrix on
00840                 //! \param columnStart The index of the column to start the submatrix on
00841                 //! \param columnEnd The index of the column to stop the submatrix on
00842                 SubMatrixAliasConstant(const MatrixAliasConstant& original, const unsigned int rowStart, const unsigned int rowEnd, const unsigned int columnStart, const unsigned int columnEnd) :
00843                         MatrixAliasConstant(m_subMatrixContainer = new SubMatrixContainer(original.m_matrixContainer, rowStart, rowEnd, columnStart, columnEnd), new SubMatrixReadAccess(this))
00844                         {_constructSubMatrixAliasConstant();}
00845 
00846                 //! \brief Copy constructor
00847                 //!
00848                 //! Makes a copy of another submatrix.
00849                 //! \param copy Reaference to submatrix to copy
00850                 SubMatrixAliasConstant(const SubMatrixAliasConstant& copy) :
00851                         MatrixAliasConstant(m_subMatrixContainer = new SubMatrixContainer(*copy.m_subMatrixContainer), new SubMatrixReadAccess(this))
00852                         {_constructSubMatrixAliasConstant();}
00853 
00854 
00855         protected:
00856                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00857                 //         Constructor Functions
00858                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00859 
00860                 //! \brief Container constructor
00861                 //!
00862                 //! Creates a new SubMatrixContainer and SubMatrixReadAccess, and passes the handles
00863                 //! back to MatrixAliasConstant
00864                 void _constructSubMatrixAliasConstant();
00865 
00866                 //! \brief SubContainer constructor
00867                 //!
00868                 //! Creates a new SubMatrixContainer from a copy of an existing one, and a
00869                 //! new SubMatrixReadAccess, then passes the handles
00870                 //! back to MatrixAliasConstant
00871                 //! \param original_subContainer Pointer to the subMatrix's container class (to make a copy of)
00872                 //void _constructSubMatrixAliasConstant(const SubMatrixContainer * original_subContainer);
00873 
00874         public:
00875                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00876                 //         Destructor
00877                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00878 
00879                 //! \brief SubMatrixAliasConstant Destructor
00880                 //!
00881                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
00882                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
00883                 virtual ~SubMatrixAliasConstant();
00884 
00885                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00886                 //         Overloaded Operators
00887                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00888 
00889                 //! Base class assignment operator
00890                 SubMatrixAliasConstant& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {m_matrixReadAccess->error("Tried to assign to a constant sub-matrix\n");return *this;}
00891 
00892                 //! Assignment operator
00893                 SubMatrixAliasConstant& operator=(const SubMatrixAliasConstant& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
00894 
00895 
00896 };
00897 
00898 
00899 //! \brief Accesses just a portion of a matrix (and provides write access).
00900 //! \author Lee Netherton
00901 //!
00902 //! The SubMatrixAlias class can be useful for "masking" out, all but
00903 //! the useful parts of a matrix. One particulary useful feature of
00904 //! the SubMatrixAlias class comes about when you use them in conjunction
00905 //! with the MatrixAlias::subMatrixAlias() operator function. Suppose you
00906 //! have two matrices, and you wanted to make one portion of one matrix
00907 //! equal to a portion of the other. The two matrices look like this:
00908 //! \code
00909 //!  Matrix 1:           Matrix 2:
00910 //!
00911 //!  [ a  b  c  d ]      [ q  r  s  t ]
00912 //!  [ e  f  g  h ]      [ u  v  w  x ]
00913 //!  [ i  j  k  l ]      [ y  z  1  2 ]
00914 //!  [ m  n  o  p ]      [ 3  4  5  6 ]
00915 //! \endcode
00916 //! If we wanted to make the top right portion of Matrix 1 equal to the top right
00917 //! corner of Matrix 2 we could do:
00918 //! \code
00919 //! mat1.subMatrixAlias(0,1,2,3) = mat2.subMatrixAlias(0,1,2,3);
00920 //! \endcode
00921 //! The matrices would then look like this:
00922 //! \code
00923 //!  Matrix 1:           Matrix 2:
00924 //!
00925 //!  [ a  b  s  t ]      [ q  r  s  t ]
00926 //!  [ e  f  w  x ]      [ u  v  w  x ]
00927 //!  [ i  j  k  l ]      [ y  z  1  2 ]
00928 //!  [ m  n  o  p ]      [ 3  4  5  6 ]
00929 //! \endcode
00930 class SubMatrixAlias : public SubMatrixAliasConstant, public MatrixAlias
00931 {
00932         public:
00933 
00934                 //! \brief Pointer constructor.
00935                 //!
00936                 //! Creates a SubMatrixAlias from a pointer to another matrix. The other values
00937                 //! are the start and end rows and columns for the submatrix.
00938                 //! See SubMatrixAliasConstant() for more details.
00939                 //!
00940                 //! \param original Pointer to the matrix to be aliased
00941                 //! \param rowStart The index of the row to start the submatrix on
00942                 //! \param rowEnd The index of the row to stop the submatrix on
00943                 //! \param columnStart The index of the column to start the submatrix on
00944                 //! \param columnEnd The index of the column to stop the submatrix on
00945                 SubMatrixAlias(const MatrixAliasConstant * original, const unsigned int rowStart, const unsigned int rowEnd, const unsigned int columnStart, const unsigned int columnEnd) :
00946                         MatrixAliasConstant(m_subMatrixContainer = new SubMatrixContainer(original->m_matrixContainer, rowStart, rowEnd, columnStart, columnEnd), new SubMatrixReadAccess(this)),
00947                         MatrixAlias(0, 0, new SubMatrixWriteAccess(this)),
00948                         SubMatrixAliasConstant(original, rowStart, rowEnd, columnStart, columnEnd)
00949                         {_constructSubMatrixAlias();}
00950 
00951                 //! \brief Reference constructor.
00952                 //!
00953                 //! Creates a SubMatrixAlias from a reference to another matrix. The other values
00954                 //! are the start and end rows and columns for the submatrix.
00955                 //! \param original Reference to the matrix to be aliased
00956                 //! \param rowStart The index of the row to start the submatrix on
00957                 //! \param rowEnd The index of the row to stop the submatrix on
00958                 //! \param columnStart The index of the column to start the submatrix on
00959                 //! \param columnEnd The index of the column to stop the submatrix on
00960                 SubMatrixAlias(const MatrixAliasConstant& original, const unsigned int rowStart, const unsigned int rowEnd, const unsigned int columnStart, const unsigned int columnEnd) :
00961                         MatrixAliasConstant(m_subMatrixContainer = new SubMatrixContainer(original.m_matrixContainer, rowStart, rowEnd, columnStart, columnEnd), new SubMatrixReadAccess(this)),
00962                         MatrixAlias(0, 0, new SubMatrixWriteAccess(this)),
00963                         SubMatrixAliasConstant(&original, rowStart, rowEnd, columnStart, columnEnd)
00964                         {_constructSubMatrixAlias();}
00965 
00966                 //! \brief Copy constructor
00967                 //!
00968                 //! Makes a copy of another submatrix.
00969                 //! \param copy Reaference to submatrix to copy
00970                 SubMatrixAlias(const SubMatrixAlias& copy) :
00971                         MatrixAliasConstant(m_subMatrixContainer = new SubMatrixContainer(*copy.m_subMatrixContainer), new SubMatrixReadAccess(this)),
00972                         MatrixAlias(0, 0, new SubMatrixWriteAccess(this)),
00973                         SubMatrixAliasConstant(copy)
00974                         {_constructSubMatrixAlias();}
00975 
00976         protected:
00977                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00978                 //         Constructor Functions
00979                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00980 
00981                 //! \brief Container constructor
00982                 //!
00983                 //! Creates a new SubMatrixContainer and SubMatrixWriteAccess, and passes the handles
00984                 //! back to SubMatrixAliasConstant
00985                 void _constructSubMatrixAlias();
00986 
00987                 //! \brief SubContainer constructor
00988                 //!
00989                 //! Creates a new SubMatrixContainer from a copy of an existing one, and a
00990                 //! new SubMatrixWriteAccess, then passes the handles
00991                 //! back to SubMatrixAliasConstant
00992                 //! \param original_subContainer Pointer to the subMatrix's container class (to make a copy of)
00993                 //void _constructSubMatrixAlias(const SubMatrixContainer * original_subContainer);
00994 
00995         public:
00996 
00997                 //------------------------------------------------------------
00998                 //         Destructor
00999                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01000 
01001                 //! \brief SubMatrixAlias Destructor
01002                 //!
01003                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
01004                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
01005                 virtual ~SubMatrixAlias();
01006 
01007                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01008                 //         Overloaded Operators
01009                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01010 
01011                 //! Base class assignment operator
01012                 SubMatrixAlias& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {equals(copy);return *this;}
01013 
01014                 //! Assignment operator
01015                 SubMatrixAlias& operator=(const SubMatrixAlias& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
01016 
01017 };

01020 //! \brief A read-only SquareMatrixAlias class.
01021 //! \author Lee Netherton
01022 //!
01023 //! The SquareMatrixAliasConstant class provides all the functionality from the MatrixAliasConstant
01024 //! class, but add specific functions intended for square matricies (like inverse(), and determinant()).
01025 //!
01026 class SquareMatrixAliasConstant : virtual public MatrixAliasConstant
01027 {
01028         public:
01029                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01030                 //         MatrixOperator Members
01031                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01032 
01033                 //! Returns the determinant of this matrix (uses LU decomposition)
01034                 SqMRO_DeterminantLUDecomp determinant;
01035 
01036                 //! Returns the determinant of this matrix (uses basic algorithm)
01037                 SqMRO_DeterminantBasic determinant2;
01038 
01039                 //! Returns the cofactor of an element
01040                 SqMRO_Cofactor cofactor;
01041 
01042                 //! Returns the inverse of this matrix (uses LU decomposition)
01043                 SqMRO_InverseLUDecomp inverse;
01044 
01045                 //! Returns the inverse of this matrix (uses basic algorithm)
01046                 SqMRO_InverseBasic inverse2;
01047 
01048                 //! Returns the matrix exponential using irreducible Pade approximation.
01049                 SqMRO_Exponential exponential;
01050 
01051                 //! Returns an LU decomposition of this matrix
01052                 SqMRO_LUDecomposition luDecomposition;
01053 
01054                 //! Returns an LU back substitution of this matrix
01055                 SqMRO_LUBackSubstitution luBackSubstitution;
01056 
01057 
01058                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01059                 //         Constructors
01060                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01061 
01062                 //! \brief Default constructor.
01063                 //!
01064                 //! Creates a SquareMatrixAliasConstant shell. The MatrixContainer and MatrixReadAccess
01065                 //! handles can be set later using the constructor function _constructSquareMatrixAliasConstant()
01066                 //SquareMatrixAliasConstant() {_constructSquareMatrixAliasConstant();}
01067 
01068                 //! \brief Pointer constructor
01069                 //!
01070                 //! To create a read-only square matrix that will access a pre-available data array.
01071                 //! \param data Pointer to data array. This will be the data storage for the matrix.
01072                 //! \param size Number of rows and columns the matrix has.
01073                 SquareMatrixAliasConstant(const double * data, const unsigned int size) : MatrixAliasConstant(data, size, size) {_constructSquareMatrixAliasConstant();}
01074 
01075                 //! \brief Alias constructor
01076                 //!
01077                 //! To create a read-only square matrix that will alias another matrix.
01078                 //! \param alias Pointer to a matrix which this matris will alias.
01079                 SquareMatrixAliasConstant(const MatrixAliasConstant* alias) : MatrixAliasConstant(alias->getDataPointer(), alias->getRows(), alias->getColumns()) {_constructSquareMatrixAliasConstant();}
01080 
01081                 //! \brief Base class copy constructor
01082                 //!
01083                 //! Used when creating a SquareMatrixAliasConstant matrix from another.
01084                 //! \code SquareMatrixAliasConstant newSqMAC(oldSqMAC); \endcode
01085                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.
01086                 SquareMatrixAliasConstant(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) : MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()) {_constructSquareMatrixAliasConstant();}
01087 
01088                 //! \brief Copy constructor
01089                 //!
01090                 //! Used when creating a MatrixAliasConstant matrix from another. Calls
01091                 //! base class copy constructor
01092                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.
01093                 SquareMatrixAliasConstant(const SquareMatrixAliasConstant& copy) : MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()) {_constructSquareMatrixAliasConstant();}
01094 
01095         protected:
01096                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01097                 //         Constructor Functions
01098                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01099 
01100                 //! \brief Blank constructor
01101                 //!
01102                 //! Just constructs SquareMatrixAliasConstant operators, and goes no further.
01103                 void _constructSquareMatrixAliasConstant();
01104 
01105         private:
01106                 //! \brief Operator constructor
01107                 //!
01108                 //! Constructs all the SquareMatrixAliasConstant operator objects
01109                 void _constructSquareMatrixAliasConstantOperators();
01110 
01111         public:
01112                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01113                 //         Destructor
01114                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01115 
01116                 //! \brief SquareMatrixAliasConstant Destructor
01117                 //!
01118                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
01119                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
01120                 virtual ~SquareMatrixAliasConstant();
01121 
01122                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01123                 //         Overloaded Operators
01124                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01125 
01126                 //! Base class assignment operator
01127                 SquareMatrixAliasConstant& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {m_matrixReadAccess->error("Tried to assign to a constant square matrix\n");return *this;}
01128 
01129                 //! Assignment operator
01130                 SquareMatrixAliasConstant& operator=(const SquareMatrixAliasConstant& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
01131 
01132 
01133 };

01136 //! \brief A SquareMatrixAlias class.
01137 //! \author Lee Netherton
01138 //!
01139 //! The SquareMatrixAlias class provides all the functionality from the MatrixAlias
01140 //! class, but add specific functions intended for square matricies (like inverse(), and determinant()).
01141 //! It also has specific square matrix write functions like identity().
01142 //!
01143 class SquareMatrixAlias : virtual public MatrixAlias, public SquareMatrixAliasConstant
01144 {
01145         public:
01146                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01147                 //         MatrixOperator Members
01148                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01149 
01150                 //! Makes this matrix an identity matrix
01151                 SqMWO_Identity identity;
01152 
01153                 //! Makes this matrix direction cosine matrix
01154                 SqMWO_DirectionCosine directionCosine;
01155 
01156                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01157                 //         Constructors
01158                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01159

01161                 //!
01162                 //! Creates a SquareMatrixAlias shell. The MatrixContainer, MatrixReadAccess and MatrixWriteAccess
01163                 //! handles can be set later using the constructor function _constructSquareMatrixAlias()
01164                 //SquareMatrixAlias() {_constructSquareMatrixAlias();}
01165 
01166                 //! \brief Pointer constructor
01167                 //!
01168                 //! To create a square matrix that will access a pre-available data array.
01169                 //! \param data Pointer to data array. This will be the data storage for the matrix.
01170                 //! \param size Number of rows and columns the matrix has.
01171                 SquareMatrixAlias(const double * data, const unsigned int size) :
01172                         MatrixAliasConstant(data, size, size),
01173                         MatrixAlias(data, size, size),
01174                         SquareMatrixAliasConstant(data, size)
01175                         {_constructSquareMatrixAlias();}
01176 
01177                 //! \brief Alias constructor
01178                 //!
01179                 //! To create a square matrix that will alias another matrix.
01180                 //! \param alias Pointer to a matrix which this matrix will alias.

01182                         MatrixAliasConstant(alias->getDataPointer(), alias->getRows(), alias->getColumns()),
01183                         MatrixAlias(alias->getDataPointer(), alias->getRows(), alias->getColumns()),
01184                         SquareMatrixAliasConstant(alias->getDataPointer(), alias->getRows())
01185                         {_constructSquareMatrixAlias();}

01191                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.

01193                         MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()),
01194                         MatrixAlias(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()),
01195                         SquareMatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows())
01196                         {_constructSquareMatrixAlias();}
01197 
01198                 //! \brief Copy constructor
01199                 //!
01200                 //! Used when creating a SquareMatrixAlias matrix from another. Calls
01201                 //! base class copy constructor
01202                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.
01203                 SquareMatrixAlias(const SquareMatrixAlias& copy) :
01204                         MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()),
01205                         MatrixAlias(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows(), copy.getColumns()),
01206                         SquareMatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getRows())
01207                         {_constructSquareMatrixAlias();}
01208 
01209         protected:
01210                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01211                 //         Constructor Functions
01212                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01213 
01214                 //! \brief Blank constructor
01215                 //!
01216                 //! Just constructs SquareMatrixAlias and SquareMatrixAliasConstant operators, and goes no further.
01217                 void _constructSquareMatrixAlias();
01218 
01219         private:
01220                 //! \brief Operator constructor
01221                 //!
01222                 //! Constructs all the SquareMatrixAlias operator objects
01223                 void _constructSquareMatrixAliasOperators();
01224 
01225         public:
01226                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01227                 //         Destructor
01228                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01229 
01230                 //! \brief SquareMatrixAlias Destructor
01231                 //!
01232                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
01233                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
01234                 virtual ~SquareMatrixAlias();
01235 
01236                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01237                 //         Overloaded Operators
01238                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01239

01241                 SquareMatrixAlias& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {equals(copy);return *this;}
01242 
01243                 //! Assignment operator
01244                 SquareMatrixAlias& operator=(const SquareMatrixAlias& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
01245 
01246 };

01249 //! \brief The standard SquareMatrix class.
01250 //! \author Lee Netherton
01251 //!
01252 //! The SquareMatrix class provides the user with a pre made square matrix. It will allocate
01253 //! its own memory, and is provided with a full complement of matrix and square matrix operators.
01254 //!
01255 class SquareMatrix : public Matrix, public SquareMatrixAlias
01256 {
01257         public:
01258                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01259                 //         MatrixOperator Members
01260                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01261 
01262                 //! Checks to see if the operand is compatable (i.e. square) and then copies data in.
01263                 SqMWO_EqualsElementCopyResize equals;
01264 
01265                 //! Resize operator Resize matrix (allocate new memory if number of elements changes).
01266                 SqMWO_Resize resize;
01267 
01268                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01269                 //         Constructors
01270                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01271 
01272                 //! \brief Default constructor.
01273                 //!
01274                 //! Creates a Matrix shell.
01275                 SquareMatrix() :
01276                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[1], 1, 1),
01277                         MatrixAlias(0, 1, 1),
01278                         Matrix(1, 1),
01279                         SquareMatrixAlias(0, 1)
01280                         {_constructSquareMatrix();}
01281 
01282                 //! \brief Sized constructor.
01283                 //!
01284                 //! Creates a new square matrix of a given size.
01285                 //! \param size Number of rows and columns matrix has
01286                 SquareMatrix(const unsigned int size) :
01287                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[size*size], size, size),
01288                         MatrixAlias(0, size, size),
01289                         Matrix(size, size),
01290                         SquareMatrixAlias(0, size)
01291                         {_constructSquareMatrix();}
01292 
01293                 //! \brief Base class copy constructor
01294                 //!
01295                 //! Makes a copy of any another matrix.
01296                 //! \param copy Reaference to matrix to copy
01297                 SquareMatrix(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) :
01298                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[copy.getRows()*copy.getColumns()], copy.getRows(),copy.getColumns()),
01299                         MatrixAlias(0, copy.getRows(),copy.getColumns()),
01300                         Matrix(copy.getRows(),copy.getColumns()),
01301                         SquareMatrixAlias(0, copy.getRows())
01302                         {_constructSquareMatrix(copy);}
01303 
01304                 //! \brief Copy constructor
01305                 //!
01306                 //! Makes a copy of another matrix.
01307                 //! \param copy Reaference to matrix to copy
01308                 SquareMatrix(const SquareMatrix& copy) :
01309                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[copy.getRows()*copy.getColumns()], copy.getRows(),copy.getColumns()),
01310                         MatrixAlias(0, copy.getRows(),copy.getColumns()),
01311                         Matrix(copy.getRows(),copy.getColumns()),
01312                         SquareMatrixAlias(0, copy.getRows())
01313                         {_constructSquareMatrix(copy);}
01314 
01315         protected:
01316                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01317                 //         Constructor Functions
01318                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01319 
01320                 //! \brief Sized constructor.
01321                 //!
01322                 //! Allocates some memory, and calls the Matrix constructor function and
01323                 //! the SquareMatrixAlias blank constructor function.
01324                 void _constructSquareMatrix();
01325 
01326                 //! \brief Copy constructor
01327                 //!
01328                 //! Allocates some memory, and calls the Matrix constructor function and
01329                 //! the SquareMatrixAlias blank constructor function.
01330                 //! Finally, copys data in from copied matrix
01331                 //! \param copy Matrix to copy
01332                 void _constructSquareMatrix(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy);
01333 
01334         private:
01335                 //! \brief Operator constructor
01336                 //!
01337                 //! Constructs all the SquareMatrix operator objects
01338                 void _constructSquareMatrixOperators();
01339 
01340         public:
01341 
01342                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01343                 //         Destructor
01344                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01345 
01346                 //! \brief SquareMatrix Destructor
01347                 //!
01348                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
01349                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
01350                 virtual ~SquareMatrix();
01351 
01352                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01353                 //         Overloaded Operators
01354                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01355 
01356                 //! Base class assignment operator
01357                 SquareMatrix& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {equals(copy);return *this;}
01358 
01359                 //! Assignment operator
01360                 SquareMatrix& operator=(const SquareMatrix& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
01361 
01362 
01363 };
01364 
01365 //! \brief A read-only RowVectorAlias class.
01366 //! \author Lee Netherton
01367 //!
01368 //! The RowVectorAliasConstant class provides all the functionality from the MatrixAliasConstant
01369 //! class, but add specific functions intended for row vectors.
01370 //!
01371 class RowVectorAliasConstant : virtual public MatrixAliasConstant
01372 {
01373         public:
01374                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01375                 //         MatrixOperator Members
01376                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01377 
01378                 //! Returns the cross product of this vector
01379                 RVRO_CrossProduct cross;
01380 
01381                 //! Returns the dot product of this vector
01382                 RVRO_DotProduct dot;
01383 
01384                 //! Returns a normalised version of this vector
01385                 RVRO_Direction direction;
01386 
01387                 //! Returns the size of this vector
01388                 RVRO_GetSize getSize;
01389 
01390                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01391                 //         Constructors
01392                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01393 
01394                 //! \brief Default constructor.
01395                 //!
01396                 //! Creates a RowVectorAliasConstant shell. The MatrixContainer and MatrixReadAccess
01397                 //! handles can be set later using the constructor function _constructRowVectorAliasConstant()
01398                 //RowVectorAliasConstant() {_constructRowVectorAliasConstant();}
01399 
01400                 //! \brief Pointer constructor
01401                 //!
01402                 //! To create a read-only row vector that will access a pre-available data array.
01403                 //! \param data Pointer to data array. This will be the data storage for the matrix.
01404                 //! \param size Number of columns the matrix has.
01405                 RowVectorAliasConstant(const double * data, const unsigned int size) :
01406                         MatrixAliasConstant(data, 1, size)
01407                         {_constructRowVectorAliasConstant();}
01408 
01409                 //! \brief Alias constructor
01410                 //!
01411                 //! To create a read-only row vector that will alias another matrix.
01412                 //! \param alias Pointer to a matrix which this matris will alias.
01413                 RowVectorAliasConstant(const MatrixAliasConstant* alias) :
01414                         MatrixAliasConstant(alias->getDataPointer(), 1, alias->getColumns())
01415                         {_constructRowVectorAliasConstant();}
01416 
01417                 //! \brief Base class copy constructor
01418                 //!
01419                 //! Used when creating a RowVectorAliasConstant matrix from another.
01420                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.
01421                 RowVectorAliasConstant(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) :
01422                         MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), 1, copy.getColumns())
01423                         {_constructRowVectorAliasConstant();}
01424 
01425                 //! \brief Copy constructor
01426                 //!
01427                 //! Used when creating a MatrixAliasConstant matrix from another. Calls
01428                 //! base class copy constructor
01429                 //! \param copy Reference to another matrix.
01430                 RowVectorAliasConstant(const RowVectorAliasConstant& copy) :
01431                         MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), 1, copy.getColumns())
01432                         {_constructRowVectorAliasConstant();}
01433 
01434         protected:
01435                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01436                 //         Constructor Functions
01437                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01438 
01439                 //! \brief Blank constructor
01440                 //!
01441                 //! Just constructs RowVectorAliasConstant operators, and goes no further.
01442                 void _constructRowVectorAliasConstant();
01443 
01444         private:
01445                 //! \brief Operator constructor
01446                 //!
01447                 //! Constructs all the RowVectorAliasConstant operator objects
01448                 void _constructRowVectorAliasConstantOperators();
01449 
01450         public:
01451                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01452                 //         Destructor
01453                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01454 
01455                 //! \brief RowVectorAliasConstant Destructor
01456                 //!
01457                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
01458                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
01459                 virtual ~RowVectorAliasConstant();
01460 
01461                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01462                 //         Overloaded Operators
01463                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01464 
01465                 //! Base class assignment operator
01466                 RowVectorAliasConstant& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {m_matrixReadAccess->error("Tried to assign to a constant vector\n");return *this;}
01467 
01468                 //! Assignment operator
01469                 RowVectorAliasConstant& operator=(const RowVectorAliasConstant& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
01470 
01471 };

01473 //! \brief A RowVectorAlias class.
01474 //! \author Lee Netherton
01475 //!
01476 //! The RowVectorAlias class provides all the functionality from the MatrixAlias
01477 //! class, but add specific functions intended for row vectors.
01478 //! It also has specific row vector write functions.
01479 //!
01480 class RowVectorAlias : public RowVectorAliasConstant, virtual public MatrixAlias
01481 {
01482         public:
01483                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01484                 //         MatrixOperator Members
01485                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01486 
01487                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01488                 //         Constructors
01489                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01490

01492                 //!
01493                 //! Creates a RowVectorAlias shell. The MatrixContainer, MatrixReadAccess and MatrixWriteAccess
01494                 //! handles can be set later using the constructor function _constructRowVectorAlias()
01495                 //RowVectorAlias() {_constructRowVectorAlias();}
01496 
01497                 //! \brief Pointer constructor
01498                 //!
01499                 //! To create a row vector that will access a pre-available data array.
01500                 //! \param data Pointer to data array. This will be the data storage for the matrix.
01501                 //! \param size Number of columns the vector has.

01503                         MatrixAliasConstant(data, 1, size),
01504                         MatrixAlias(data, 1, size),
01505                         RowVectorAliasConstant(data, size)
01506                         {_constructRowVectorAlias();}

01513                         MatrixAliasConstant(alias->getDataPointer(), 1, alias->getColumns()),
01514                         MatrixAlias(alias->getDataPointer(), 1, alias->getColumns()),
01515                         RowVectorAliasConstant(alias->getDataPointer(), alias->getColumns())
01516                         {_constructRowVectorAlias();}
01517

01523                         MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), 1, copy.getColumns()),

01526                         {_constructRowVectorAlias();}

01531                 //! base class copy constructor
01532                 //! \param copy Reference to another row vector.
01533                 RowVectorAlias(const RowVectorAlias& copy) :
01534                         MatrixAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), 1, copy.getColumns()),
01535                         MatrixAlias(copy.getDataPointer(), 1, copy.getColumns()),
01536                         RowVectorAliasConstant(copy.getDataPointer(), copy.getColumns())
01537                         {_constructRowVectorAlias();}

01541                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01542                 //         Constructor Functions
01543                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01544

01548                 void _constructRowVectorAlias();
01549

01580 //! \brief The standard RowVector class.
01581 //! \author Lee Netherton
01582 //!
01583 //! The RowVector class provides the user with a pre made row vector. It will allocate
01584 //! its own memory, and is provided with a full complement of matrix and row vector operators.
01585 //!
01586 class RowVector : public Matrix, public RowVectorAlias
01587 {
01588         public:
01589                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01590                 //         MatrixOperator Members
01591                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01592 
01593                 //! Checks to see if the operand is compatable (i.e. a row vector) and then copies data in.
01594                 RVWO_EqualsElementCopyResize equals;
01595 
01596                 //! Resize operator Resize matrix (allocate new memory if number of elements changes).
01597                 RVWO_Resize resize;
01598 
01599                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01600                 //         Constructors
01601                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01602 
01603                 //! \brief Default constructor.
01604                 //!
01605                 //! Creates a Matrix shell.
01606                 RowVector() :
01607                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[1], 1, 1),
01608                         MatrixAlias(0, 1, 1),
01609                         Matrix(1, 1),
01610                         RowVectorAlias(0, 1)
01611                         {_constructRowVector();}
01612 
01613                 //! \brief Sized constructor.
01614                 //!
01615                 //! Creates a new row vector of a given size.
01616                 //! \param size Number of columns matrix has
01617                 RowVector(const unsigned int size) :
01618                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[size], 1, size),
01619                         MatrixAlias(0, 1, size),
01620                         Matrix(1, size),
01621                         RowVectorAlias(0, size)
01622                         {_constructRowVector();}
01623 
01624                 //! \brief Base class copy constructor
01625                 //!
01626                 //! Makes a copy of any another matrix.
01627                 //! \param copy Reaference to matrix to copy
01628                 RowVector(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) :
01629                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[copy.getColumns()], 1, copy.getColumns()),
01630                         MatrixAlias(0, 1, copy.getColumns()),
01631                         Matrix(1, copy.getColumns()),
01632                         RowVectorAlias(0, copy.getColumns())
01633                         {_constructRowVector(copy);}
01634 
01635                 //! \brief Copy constructor
01636                 //!
01637                 //! Makes a copy of another matrix.
01638                 //! \param copy Reaference to matrix to copy
01639                 RowVector(RowVector& copy) :
01640                         MatrixAliasConstant(new double[copy.getColumns()], 1, copy.getColumns()),
01641                         MatrixAlias(0, 1, copy.getColumns()),
01642                         Matrix(1, copy.getColumns()),
01643                         RowVectorAlias(0, copy.getColumns())
01644                         {_constructRowVector(copy);}
01645 
01646         protected:
01647                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01648                 //         Constructor Functions
01649                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01650 
01651                 //! \brief Sized constructor.
01652                 //!
01653                 //! Allocates some memory, and calls the Matrix constructor function and
01654                 //! the RowVectorAlias blank constructor function.
01655                 void _constructRowVector();
01656 
01657                 //! \brief Copy constructor
01658                 //!
01659                 //! Allocates some memory, and calls the Matrix constructor function and
01660                 //! the RowVectorAlias blank constructor function.
01661                 //! Finally, copys data in from copied matrix
01662                 //! \param copy Matrix to copy
01663                 void _constructRowVector(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy);
01664 
01665         private:
01666                 //! \brief Operator constructor
01667                 //!
01668                 //! Constructs all the SquareMatrix operator objects
01669                 void _constructRowVectorOperators();
01670 
01671         public:
01672                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01673                 //         Destructor
01674                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01675 
01676                 //! \brief RowVector Destructor
01677                 //!
01678                 //! Virtual - the lowest derived class will always need to be called, as they
01679                 //! all allocate memory in ther own ways.
01680                 virtual ~RowVector();
01681 
01682                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01683                 //         Overloaded Operators
01684                 //------------------------------------------------------------
01685 
01686                 //! Base class assignment operator
01687                 RowVector& operator=(const MatrixAliasConstant& copy) {equals(copy);return *this;}
01688 
01689                 //! Assignment operator
01690                 RowVector& operator=(const RowVector& copy) {return operator=((MatrixAliasConstant&)copy);}
01691 
01692 };

01993                 //! the ColumnVectorAlias blank constructor function.
01994                 //! Finally, copys data in from copied matrix
